headline: Positive Work Atmosphere
pros: Great location, free shuttle transportation provided to and from the city, generally positive work environment
cons: Management and leadership needs overall improvement

headline: Great place to work
pros:
1. Strong work ethics from management down to local teams
2. Collaborative and transparent culture, little to no office politics
3. Fair compensation
cons: Processes and systems are a bit old and outdated

headline: Great company, smart people
pros: Coworkers feel like family - great sense of community
cons: Employees are given small annual raises

headline: Supportive digital newsroom growing in influence
pros:
Current management has successfully increased the reach and influence of cnbc.com
Newsroom managers challenge reporters to be the best on their beat
Strong loyalty to staff, efforts made to promote from within
Very friendly and supportive atmosphere where both personal and professional milestones are celebrated
Excellent support from photo and graphics staff
Competitive pay and benefits
cons:
Pay is very competitive but not top-tier relative to peers
Benefit package at time of employment had room for improvement
Career advancement and pay could be limited based on the subject-area interests and priorities of upper-level editorial executives
Long commute for New York City-based employees (though company provides transportation)

headline: Front end engineer
pros:
- gym
- free parking
- good work life balance
cons: cannot recall any cons so far

headline: Fair Wage
pros: Paid hourly no matter base location
cons: I don’t have any cons

headline: News Assistant
pros:
- Good company benefits
- Professionalism at work

cons:
- Lower pay
- Stagnant upward mobility

headline: Top heavy, toxic, but some highly rewarding qualities
pros:
Free cab rides in 
Good welfare (meals, care packages, celebrations)
Top notch medical insurance
A long-staying boss that is a gem of a person
Understanding bosses
You never take work home
cons:
Meagre pay unless you've gotten 5-6 years in (no kidding, can't even apply for a credit card with the entry level salary)
Horrendous start hours - 3 am start times, but could be attractive to those who can do it
Lots of toxic personalities that gaslight and dump work, shout expletives and scream
Promotions take too long

headline: First in business worldwide
pros:
Efficiently operated international newsroom.
Great resources and dedication in pursuit of bringing exclusive stories.
cons: There will be no cons if you are open to soaking in the experience of being part of a global news network.

headline: Outstanding work culture
pros: Friendly work environment with understanding management
cons: I am not telling you!

headline: Positive work environment

Excellent Work Schedule for TV

headline: BULLIES!!
pros: This place has no pros. Read the cons!
cons: Some of the old timers there were pure bullies. Used abusive language all day in the control room and in the newsroom. To top it all the top management is absolutely okay with the abusive behaviour in the Singapore office! Toxic place.

headline: news editor

headline: CNBC Africa
pros: They are the only pan-African business news channel.It's a very exciting environment to work in.As a crew member, it really expands your horizons.It also opens doors if you let it.I built great relationships during my employ, and continue to enjoy close friendships with many of my former colleagues.
cons: Inter-departmental communication needs to be improved.

headline: Great brand and some amazing people but leadership needs to be more open to change
pros:
Some amazing people with strong loyalty and integrity.
Strong brand.
Opportunity to get involved in many projects often at a higher-level than you're employed for. This makes it a great learning experience and great for your CV to find another job somewhere else.
cons:
Leadership are set in their ways and need to be more open to change.
Limited resources and investment means the business relies on the goodwill of employees and pushing them hard so the organisation can punch above its weight.
Pay is low compared to the market and key competitors.
Some teams are very clique which means if you're not in the clique life can be tough.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good work culture, Nice people to work
cons: Don't have public transit to commute. Should have a car.

headline: Good people

cons: no cons here as yet

headline: Small but aggressive and dominant newsroom
pros: Supportive, flexible, exciting workplace. Real team environment. Lots of amenities when the office is open.
cons: Team can be a bit too small, leaving stories to fall through the cracks. Communication between TV and digital operations is inconsistent.

headline: Bad

pros: Excellent place to work in broadcast journalism. Family friendly. Good community of workers. High standards. Not partisan.
cons: CNBC is such a desirable place to work that turnover is low, so breaking in and moving up is hard.

headline: Great Company
pros: Great environment, learning process, good salary amd great benefits

cons: Management works under status quo mentality, occasional outbursts by management and execs in unprofessional situations. Supervisors who get off making constant threats.

headline: Great place to grow your career
pros: CNBC is a great place to get started as a journalist. It gives you the practical experience you need to develop skills in the field, particularly in breaking news and building contacts.
cons: One of the main drawbacks is getting past the later stages of promotion. You can sometimes find yourself waiting a few years in junior positions before progressing.

headline: CNBC

headline: Good

headline: CNBC more than just money.
pros:
Great benefits as part of NBC Universal. This includes lots of training opportunities.
Friendly employees.
Great gym
cons:
The location is horrible - very isolated for those coming from the city. You will need a car to leave the building which is a bummer.

 Also its tough to get promoted. Many people stay in the same role for many years.

headline: Job

cons: company culture, benefits, pay, people, no opportunities, no training

headline: What are these employees eating?
pros:
Share responsibilities with the facilities janitor
Free food after it enters the dumpster
A/C all year long
cons: Some employees apparently like to eat exotic food, I'm always finding interesting stoppages in the toilet

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Lovely people are working there.
cons: Can't think of any bad points at the moment.

headline: Good resume name, but dead end long-term
pros: good resume name, foot in door
cons:
CNBC could not care less about you. leadership making 6/7 figures while you'll never get promoted or any raises. there are people who've been there for 3-5 years without a raise or promotion, its a dead end long term. they claim to like to retain people but it's all for show. same about diversity. all talk and nothing to show for it. they'll always gaslight if you bring promotions up too. 
CNBC digital leadership also does not understand the internet and only view success by views and clicks (hence all the hate clicks). then like to put blame on team members when leadership is the problem.

headline: Good Company
pros: Great place to work, responsible, fair, respectful
cons: Not much to add for cons

headline: Digital sucks
pros: You’re part of the NBC ecosystem and they match up to 6% 401k
cons: Not much room for growth on digital. The CNBC Make It team is tragic. The work is a grind for very little pay and there’s no career progression.

headline: Great company
pros: Quality business news growth, travel, great team, fun
cons: Competitive, long hours, job security, little control, no equity

headline: Racist fame woke white women
pros: The overall nbc benefits under comcast universal

headline: Good place to start your career

headline: Great work environment

headline: Too Corporate, a modern day factory line

headline: great colleagues but managers and higher ups made this a traumatizing experience

cons: did not learn anything from the people above my peers

headline: Interesting work, pay not great
pros: Interesting work with some very bright people
cons: The pay is not great - different people are given different contracts so beware if you are hired under a third party as a contractor as you'll be paid significantly less than your peers who are actually hired by CNBC. You'll work side by side in the same newsroom, but because of the paperwork, you can be paid and apprised very differently. I found this out too late.

headline: Great group of colleagues
pros: I really enjoyed the people I worked with. Everyone pushes each other to be better and will help if you need a hand. Upper management will help you grow, though often without a change in title.
cons: Not much growth since nobody leaves.

headline: Good so far

headline: Good place but top driven

headline: Hands-on learning, but limited growth

headline: Lots of opportunities if you make them
pros: Shuttle service to the city
cons: Having to leave the city

headline: CNBC.com Digital Writers - Smart, hardworking people
pros: Management prioritizes talent and there is the possibility for both wide and niche exposure.  Knowing the process of how they verify news for the website, I'm never concerned that it's inaccurate. Highly respected among longtime viewers who have migrated online. The hours are a bit long (expect to work some 60-hour weeks if you want to move up the ranks) but pretty reasonable (rarely night or weekend shifts needed, barring breaking news). They are actually investing in the newsroom, which not many organizations can say. They are really working on being as cross-platform as possible.
cons:
In Digital, there is a lot of emphasis on speed, and a lot of emphasis on Twitter, which is not really where traffic or readership comes from.
A lot has been invested in new "lifestyle content" that may erode some of the news credibility, especially online.

headline: N/a
pros: Scope and scale of work interesting
cons: Constant change puts pressure on employees

headline: Advertising Sales Intern
pros: Friendly Working environment and free snacks fruits.
cons: Translation and negotiation requires patience and sometimes can be boring

headline: Best TV network by far
pros: The location is a huge campus that has gym, cafe, and the environment is much more relaxed than other networks
cons: Con would have to be the cafe sometimes the food is just ehhh.  But it’s convenient.  Tons of places to order around in case you’re starving

headline: Associate Producer
pros: Work stays at work and it's live TV
cons: 3am shifts for the morning news

headline: Not good
pros: Employees are friendly and warm
cons: No work life balance

headline: Going downhill quickly
pros: Nice building and good benefits but that's about it. It used to have a lot of great things going for it until new management came in.
cons: Managers don't care and target people who complain and get away with it. They also use pressure tactics to get people to quit or spread rumors about employees with coworkers. I've seen so many people leave and Go to Yahoo Finance because of this behavior.

headline: GOOD
pros: flexible , nice colleagues and do not work over time
cons: don't have too much chance to get prompted

headline: CNBC: Good resources, pay (for cable), stable environment but old fashioned, risk averse
pros: Leader in TV business news space; reasonable hours; good pay for cable
cons: Office in Jersey; risk averse, insular, clique-y culture, egos; Mark Hoffman is like Oz

headline: A good company for retirement or if you want a slow paced job
pros:
- Company culture is pretty alright
- Laidback at times, only busy during start of each quarter
cons:
- Resistant to changes
- Good for older people who wants a stable job

headline: news intern
pros: Was very easy to manage at work
cons: Can get very stressful at times

headline: Hostile Work Environment
pros: Great benefits and perks, fairbsalary, engaged CEO and junior and news teams are composed of some amazing and talented people.
cons: A hostile and negative work environment with very little in the way of career development, recognition or opportunity on offer. Working hours are incredibly long and expectations on small teams are unrealistically high making getting out and securing a new role extremely tough. Junior staff are expected to run the place as poor performance, favouritism, mis-managment and incompetence at director and VP level is left totally unchecked. Bullying and whisper campaigns from management are common and make it a very tricky place to enjoy attending daily and believe you can succeed.

headline: Digital Video
pros: Great and extremely young people on the team, free gym
cons: This isn't a place for people that like actual journalism. Headline journalism is too much of a thing on this team and then some producers rely on younger people to find the research to support the higher ups' thesis that doesn't make sense a lot of the time. Not a lot of initiative from older people on the team to diversify their skill set. Most of the younger people can shoot, edit and research very well. If they don't, they are eager to learn. Some of the seniors can't do anything of these things properly. I'll give them this though, they're really good at acting busy all day long.

headline: Great place to learn!
pros: It is a great team environment. The team is focused on growth and true reporting. Everyone is genuine and cares about the whole person which is something I appreciate.
cons: The cafeteria can be a bit weak sometimes.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Flexible hours. Helpful co workers. Experience has been pretty good
cons: None so far.  Experience has been pretty good

headline: finance team member
pros: Great line management and training.
cons: Wages are very low comparing to the market (ent. industry and in general)

headline: Security Officer
pros: Was a good quick job
cons: They did not pay well or care about their employees

headline: Marketing Executive
pros: Office in Shanghai. Best resources in financial media. Main clients are governments who want to hold business exchange forum broad.
cons: The difficult media environment in China.

headline: Awesome Place
pros: Lots of freedom, room to grow, culture that embraces excellence.
cons: None, I think it’s a great place.

headline: CNBC
pros: Good opportunity for advancement, good colleagues. Company cares about employees.
cons: Demanding work environment. Poor work/life balance.

headline: Excellent Place to Work
pros: Flexible hours, casual dress code, friendly environment, competitive compensation.
cons: Must be able to handle a fast-paced, breaking news atmosphere.

headline: Hard work but good job and pay
pros: Everyone is friendly and tries their best
cons: No cons in workinh with cnbc.

cons: Isolated if you don't have a car

headline: Great place to work in TV

cons: Very limited movement, very little opportunity for promotion or skill development.

headline: Time spent at CNBC Turkey
pros: Good pay, good hours, good benefits.
cons: It's located in the busiest part of the city

headline: editorial
pros: culture of honesty, respect for differing views
cons: limited attention span, easily distracted

headline: Bad Experience Here
pros: Clean offices. Professional environment overall. There  are some smart and talented people.  If you live in NJ, it's a great way to work in media w/o going into Manhattan.
cons: Depends on who your supervisor is. Mine was extremely inept and a bully with zero mgmt skills, but was kept at a very high ranking position anyway, pulling the wool over everyone's eyes. If you love the rush of working in the home of media which is NYC, look elsewhere. It was depressing to look outside a window and see a NJ car park (if you had a window, most cubicles didn't) People were very stuck up and clique-ey.

headline: Good company
pros: Great team and interesting work
cons: Mixed messages from management

headline: Subjective, not rational culture
pros: Part of the GE family of companies, Six-sigma, diverse talent, fast paced
cons: Hire window dressing CEO that never worked in business before and was fickle. Cared more about appearances than results.  Very subjective business with highest rank "winning" even if no logic or data. Lacks disciplined processes.

headline: NEVER work for CNBC Digital Video
pros: there are no pros at all
cons: I would say digital has the worst managers I've ever experienced

headline: it is very good to work in cnbc
pros: beacause  i am a huge fan of anil
cons: no down sides in the company

headline: Senior Producer
pros: Creative community of industry professionals
cons: Complacency for long time employees

headline: Reporter / Producer
pros: Nice team work and helpful People
cons: High Management not fair enough to handle the business

headline: Think twice ...
pros: Decent building, location, and free gym.
cons:
Where do I start? They mine the young like moles to justify paying less for more work. The contracting agencies that they use to find talent need to be regulated big time. The building though decent, is very drab and sad. People genuinely look sad and when no one is looking. There are a lot of creative people here, who seemed to be trapped.  

Cubical farms replaced actual offices
Broken equipment 
Clunky applications
Sever ignorance from young managers
Sexiest
Racist

headline: CNBC in London
pros: CNBC in London is a dynamic place to work. The newsroom is brilliant at delivering firsts and exclusives.
cons: The internal culture can be improved, no summer hours, some functions have only limited opportunities for growth unless you move to NBC Universal

headline: Great brand, but little room for growth
pros: TV experience in an established platform; great brand to have on CV; wide scope of exposure; plenty of leave days.
cons: Little room for growth; responsibilities menial; unfavourable work hours; very hierarchical; bosses do not pay attention to staff nurturing and growth; constant manpower shortage.

headline: Great
pros: free gym, nice people, free shuttle
cons: no free food but that's not a huge deal

headline: Producer
pros: People. Life work balance.
cons: little room for career development

headline: producer
pros: great and smart colleagues. nice building, but not in New york City.  Did not love the commute
cons: Management always fighting with each other, and out of touch with employees

headline: Not bad, but not great either
pros: The majority of employees understand that we're all part of the same team and will help each other if needed...friendly work environment.  Not working on the weekends (in TV this is very rare).
cons: Not much upward mobility due to employees not leaving the company...a good sign in some regards.  Difficult for managers to accept that employees have interests outside of work and occasionally need to use their personal days...it's like pulling teeth to get personal days approved (and we're entitled to 5 days/year).  CNBC is considered the leader in business news but rarely do they want to try new ideas for programming...they're coasting and I think the viewers pick up on that.

headline: Good Experience
pros: Good experience, cutting edge technologies, funded and staffed well.
cons: Off shore dominated, expect long long hours

headline: Excellent for Broadcast Production
pros:
Experience is always subjective to your position but as a whole this is an excellent place for broadcast production personnel. Culture is inclusive, content standards are high, shifts are largely M-F days, management's communication is open & honest, and technology is on par with industry standards.
Benefits are competitive. 
20 min from Manhattan in Englewood Cliffs, NJ.
cons: I see this as a plus, but it's located on the west side of the Hudson, just barely north of the GW bridge, 20 min from Manhattan. For some people this is a con but I'd rather live on the NJ side and enter NYC when I want to so it works for me.

headline: CNBC EMEA
pros: Small team meant flexibility was encouraged. Opportunities arose on occasion to expand knowledge and skillet. Regular and guaranteed working hours.
cons: Massive division between production and technology meant there was little in the way of realistic expectations. As most production staff did not hail from a broadcast background, there was little in the way of decorum or trust in the abilities of others as often they didn't truly inserts as their own roles.

headline: Great place to learn
pros: You can learn a great deal.They throw you in the deep end.
cons: High pressured and high employee turn around. Learn what you can and move on.

headline: Great company!
pros: Great environment, fun to come in each day!
cons: Taking the shuttle to office in NJ

headline: News Associate
pros: Great foot in door to company
cons: Repetitive news cycle, bad location

headline: producer
pros: For the news business, good hours- and no holidays or weekends unless there's a really big story.nice building with corporate gym and massage therapist.
cons: They worship the young, people with little experience are promoted quickly.

headline: In transition
pros: Pan-European coverage, access to politicians, CEOs, executives for interviews, teams go across the world - though mostly TV, though increasingly some web staff.
cons: Can be long, awkward hours, still a large focus on TV first. Pays a lot less than competitors.

headline: Enter at your own Risk
pros: getting leaves is not tough
cons: limited opportunities, favoritism is common

headline: Positive Environment
pros: Fast paced, positive environment, great mentorship. Great place to learn if looking to get into business news production.
cons: Nothing negative to report really. Contract employee situation can be confusing difficult to move out of, but nothing really negative to report..

headline: Video Editor
pros: Very friendly atmosphere...they really care about you.
cons: Pay is not that great, and the merit increase is MINIMAL.

headline: Solid Experience, Lousy Pay
pros: - Incredible learning experience in business journalism
cons: - Constantly changing shifts (common in journalism jobs)

headline: CNBC International
pros: Working with passionate, creative and talented people. Opportunities are there if you are proactive about developing your own career
cons: Lack of investment in developing people and systems

headline: The Country Club Of News!
pros: Great people and environment. Majority of people here are friendly. Most don't work weekends and they have a kitchen that stays open until 7pm. There is a gym from treadmills to dumbbells that go up to 100lbs. They also hold social activities for employees. There also is an outdoor area to eat when the weather is nice.They provide shuttles for commuters from NYC to Jersey.
cons: There isn't a toaster oven in the break room and there is no pool. Other than that, they take care of their workers!

headline: Great people
pros: Dynamic, young and  friendly people
cons: Not independent due to US parent

headline: Great people/No Life Balance
pros: The people that work there are fun, great, energetic. The facility is nice. They have laundry service and access to gym. They also offer a shuttle for those that do not live in New Jersey which is a plus.
cons: No life balance. I was coming into work at 9am and leaving at 7p or 8p constantly. Manager was micro-managing. No room for growth whatsoever.

headline: Great experience
pros:
- Relevant business, interesting and entertaining place to work
- Smart people
cons: - Based in NJ, its a tough commute from the city

headline: good company
pros: always new faces and new people
cons: no close parking but parking is available

headline: Great company
pros: A lot of growth opportunities, the bar has been raised in the last year, expanding collaboaration between departments and comfortable work environment
cons: Commuting to New Jersey from the city can be tough for some of my co-workers, would rather be at 30 Rock if I were a young person

headline: Run a tight ship
pros:
Reliable employer.
They look after you.
cons:
Business and Finance Oriented.
Corporate of course.

headline: Manager
pros: Huge corporation - so lots of support in that sense
cons: Older skewing company - not on the cutting edge

headline: Production Intern
pros: Collaborative working environment. They make you feel like a full time employee. Learned how to produce television. Nice managers.
cons: Are thrown into the work without much instruction. Hard work.

headline: Technical Operations Intern at CNBC
pros: Hands on experience with Studio equipment. The internship it self was almost like a survey course. You aren't locked into one position. You get to rotate around and after the first couple of weeks your asked which area you liked best and stay with them.
cons: What you learn and get out of the internship is based heavily on who you observe. So if the person you observe isn't the greatest employee your missing out.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great place to work, lots of internal camaraderie, loyal employees. People here act like you would expect a leading brand to act. Heading in the right direction in terms of growth and innovation, I feel like I have a great future with CNBC.
cons: It's not a con for me, but NJ location is difficult for some. However, the free shuttle buses from NYC should mitigate that.

headline: Needs better work/life balance
pros: Good salary, great benefits, interesting work. I'm surrounded by a lot of smart and thoughtful people. Most are good at what they do.
cons: Morale is mixed. Little room for growth. It's discouraging to see dedicated colleagues leave for other companies that will give them more room for growth. And all aspects of the organization have trouble coordinating with each other.

headline: Executive Producer
pros: some of the smartest people with whom I've worked
cons: the commute to NJ is a soul crusher.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Friendly, intelligent staff. Good culture. Decent perks.
cons: Technology is a bit backward.

headline: CNBC
pros: So unbelievably kind and wants you to do well!
cons: Can get overworked, but gives many breaks.

headline: Digital online writer
pros: ok hours and helpful hr department
cons: power is held at the top by a small few

headline: It's fine
pros: Nice location in NJ, benefits, work life balance, gym.
cons: No room for growth. there are many that are out for themselves and will put down others they work with in order to get credit. Disappointing.

headline: Beautiful, impressive campus, great technology, many nice co-workers but no room for advancement
pros: Benefits, location, great equipment , beautiful campus, no weekend or nightly shows , rarely work on holidays, some nice people, surrounded by smart people
cons: No room for advancement, certain departments and individuals within the dept. seem to be more "superior" than others (mgr. turns head when they do something considered wrong, but scolded when you do same thing), not many shows in the building, a lot of days with nothing at all to do but expected to stare straight ahead and look busy, not challenging, kids out of college are doing same job as those who have been there for over 15 years), need more freelancers and vacation relief people, vacation days are not approved a lot of the time even with much notice bc only a few are allowed off per day,  having senority doesn't apply, need to train in house employees for higher up positions, often treated like children which makes many employees disgruntled and has been brought up in several group meetings (scolded for even glancing at phone and have to explain why you needed to look at phone etc, supposed to tell them ahead of time why we may need to glance at phone , programming can be very boring

headline: Producer
pros: Good place to work. No major complaints.
cons: None really. This is a good place.

headline: Exciting
pros: Great environment, management, team efforts, great people
cons: Lots of contract positions, nothing else

headline: Good, but not amazing
pros: The people are great to work with, and it's exciting to do something new every single day in a TV setting. Also, great benefits.
cons: Career advancement options were unclear.

headline: Learning by doing
pros: Great hands-on job, good access to leaders.
cons: Crazy working schedule, stressful environment

headline: Best place I ever worked
pros: Having worked at ABC, CBS, NBC and elsewhere - I can confidently say this is the best place I ever worked.  They appreciate behind-the-scenes talent and will reward you for it.  Your experience may vary, depending on your assignment, but in general - you'll have it better here than anywhere.  The switch from GE to Comcast was also helpful
cons: The suburban location is somewhat of a downside, but they make it easy to get there with a free NYC shuttle and car service where necessary.  Also wish there were some lunch alternatives nearby, but the cafeteria is pretty good ..

headline: I love this place
pros: Great work environment, creative atmosphere, friendly people, shuttle service for NYC residing employees free of charge
cons: I have no cons

headline: secure job
pros: Great place to work. Great management - very organized. Country club feel.
cons: Not much room for advancement. Work can get monotonous.

headline: Misleading Company
pros: Great Benefits and compensation. Good work life balance. Interesting if nothing else.
cons: Limited growth. Don't turn 50.

headline: Good environment, not so good opportunities if you're not editorial.
pros: Great people, diversity, fun culture
cons: Invisible line between editorial and operations

headline: Great
pros: Perfect. Lots of great people, great food, great opoortunities, nothing not to like about working there. It was an incredible place. Would highly recommend to anyone.
cons: I couldn't really say anything bad about it if I tried. I guess you could say the food was a little overpriced. . . maybe. But even that is a stretch.

headline: A great place but limited advancement.
pros: Great benefits. First in business.
cons: Limited diversification of subject.  They love to compliment themselves.  they do hire from within but are not open to outside talent.  If you are in one segment of the company, it's difficult to transfer elsewhere.  HR Managers don't recognize talent. It's a network with no personality.

headline: Ok...bit of a boys club
pros: Fast paced, interesting subject matter...
cons: Long commute (but the have shuttles from NYC). Once you're out there, that's pretty much it. Off putting hiring policies. they let a lot of good people go because....?

headline: Great people, lousy policies
pros: Great people to work with, most of them are committed to quality work and generating a product they can be proud of.
cons: The layers of corporate bureaucracy are staggering, and it negatively effects the workplace.

headline: cnbc
pros: not 24 hour network so less intense than others
cons: workplace is very cliquey and that can be annoying

headline: great place to start
pros: fast paced environment, great introduction to how broadcast media works
cons: salary is not competitive and not many career advancement prospects

headline: Overall a good place to work for in news
pros: Schedule (no weekends or late nights), Comcast benefits.
cons: Politics and HR. HR is supposed to retain talent, but instead, they try to keep you for the lowest salary possible.

headline: Great Company!
pros: Great working environment, everyone is friendly and willing to help. As an intern, my bosses genuinely cared about my development and challenged me. Also great company with great benefits for employees
cons: Unpaid for interns. I also had to come in early to go to New York some days, and my only reimbursement was a $300 travel stipend for the 11 weeks I was there. I also drove 1 hour each way to work everyday.

headline: If you on-air talent you're royally treated, otherwise they can care less about you
pros: Dynamic atmosphere, surrounded by brainiacs, and meet interesting people
cons: Work long hours, nobody cares about you as a person, bosses encourage people to work sick (and get others sick)

headline: CNBC Review
pros: Good work life balance and friendly team
cons: Lack opportunities to grow career. Glass ceiling.

headline: Unprofessional employees
pros: Had a great boss (Creative Director)
cons:
- As soon as my boss resigned, they assigned a Producer to handle the creative department, knowing that he had no experience or knowledge in the creative field. So i resigned.
- Outdated videos were being used.
- Employees were very lazy and unhappy

headline: Could have been a good place to work, but...
pros: News an exciting space, cable TV good business.
cons: Tension in all ranks of the organization

headline: One of the finest television media organisation in the country today
pros: The journalistic ethics remain supreme. The channel, during a breaking news events, bypasses advertisements, scheduled programming to bring to the people live coverage of any event that may occur unsceduled.
cons: Television is a beast not many could tackle. For youngsters, the work load could be tiring and at times frustrating. Also, there is always a pursuit to be on the screen, which makes it a rat race. Some journalists may find it very exhausting to run tapes or try to shove microphones to get the first byte, unlike in print journalist where this is not the norm.

headline: Too much internal politics
pros: good camaradeire, biggest name in biz news
cons: terrible management, very difficult to get ahead without internal politics, lack of qualified managers at higher level
